I could go on about the idiotic Terminator Movies of the late 1980s that were originally made in the nineteen seventies, and how ridiculous those movies were, everyone believed a walking Robot killing machine in our midst in this Century. That is a good example of suspending your disbelief that should apply to any movie watching experience for YOU to enjoy!

Kudos to Robert Deniro as being one of the busiest actors ever. (Heck if I was an actor I would be very proud to be in as many movies as he's been in.)

I guess, unfortunately, the downside to that, is that every once in a while you're going to end up in some horrible movies. This is definitely one of them.

IMO Travolta hasn't been in anything good since Grease or Saturday Night Fever. So I'm not surprised to see him doing yet another horrible acting job with a horribly fake accent.

I just can't believe that 1 great actor (Deniro), and one crappy actor (Revolta) would agree to participate in a movie with ZERO story, zero plot, zero interest.

I watched this movie for FREE via the XBOX. I thought, "what a cool deal". Now I totally understand why this movie was free.

I was the one who got ripped off.

Killing Season is an action/thriller directed by Mark Steven Johnson (Ghost Rider) which stars Robert De Niro, John Travolta and Milo Ventimiglia. It follows two veterans of the Bosnian War, an American named Benjamin (De Niro) and a Serbian named Emil (Travolta). After Emil helps Benjamin out with some car trouble, he is invited back to Benjamin's cabin in the woods for drinks to say 'thanks'. The friendship however turns stale after one of them reveals their true intentions, and it quickly becomes a case of 'cat and mouse'. Robert De Niro is one of my favourite actors of all time, so it was great to see him back in a more serious role compared to the light and fluffy films he has become accustom to in his later years. Travolta's transformation into a Serbian is partially convincing due to his dark complexion and the thick beard he has grown for the role, but his accent seems a little shaky at times. While this isn't an amazing film and it has received some fairly negative reviews due to its inaccuracies in relation to the Bosnian War, I think its main intentions were to focus on the duel between both men and how the war has effected each man's personal life. I thought it was entertaining enough, but probably won't watch it again anytime soon.

My Rating: 5.5/10 For more Movie and TV News, Reviews and Rumours go to: www.facebook.com/tvmovienews

review_title: Unconvincing and dull, at least for someone whose country's been part of the war.
review_detailed_main:
Summary says it all. If you're someone whose actually been affected by the war, it's just not convincing. The movie is really, no offense, it's not intended, American. It's like every other 'wanna be serious' Hollywood movie that you can smell a mile off.

Travolta is awful in the movie. His accent is completely wrong which is particularly noticeable in the parts where he speaks Serbian - it's just terrible. I mean, if they wanted him to speak a language other than his own, at least they could've done a better job in finding a decent dialect coach for those few sentences he used.

De Niro does a decent job, like always, but it's really not significant given the quality of the movie it self.

The war in Bosnia & Herzegovina was bloody and I have no problems with the story-line, but when an outsider does a movie on the subject, it's just obviously fake. Like Angelina Jolie's directorial debut, In The Land Of Blood And Honey, intentions of people involved were clearly noble, but they just don't really completely understand what it was like to make a movie on it - that's why they use dumb dialog and a bunch of a-thousand-times- seen-before-things to cover the holes, which clearly doesn't work!

It's not boring and it can be easily used as a time waster, but... Just not good!

review_title: Get to know some facts first
review_detailed_main:
Watched this movie only because of the De Niro's acting. I've seen all of his movies. As a Serbian living in Bosnia, I must say that you have to ask anyone on the internet or come to our country, ONLY to ask is the name Emil Kovac even serbian, there is no Emil Kovac that will say he's serbian, that's not common name for us serbians. I was surprised for De Niro to act in this roll, because of his love for Serbia and Serbians that he said several times.

I can say that historical facts about the war in Bosnia are false, but that's our destiny for everyone else to make our history as they like. You could only make true facts about names and some true facts once in a while for serbians everywhere.

Come to Bosnia - Republika Srpska, come to Serbia - Belgrade, Novi sad, Nis...and find out some true facts...

The best roles of John Travolta and Robert De Niro's careers,and I know that is a bold statement. This film shows there is no good and evil between soldiers, it is the entire concept of war who is the true embodiment of evil. These two characters were simply put on opposite sides of the same mud where blood was shed. Clearly it stayed with American soldier Benjamin (De Niro) & Serbian Terrorist Emil (Travolta). This film is an absolute must-see for action fans, suspense thrill-seekers, and fans of these talented actors. You genuinely care about both of the individuals, and see the truth in combat. The best of which our modern cinema can produce cannot be ignored.

review_title: worst than a trip to the dentist
review_detailed_main: as soon as I heard J. Travolta's fake Serbian accent, I called my dentist and told him I was going to be able to make it after all. Trying to listen to Travolta's fake accent is like pulling teeth, pure torture, he is as much Bosnian, as I am Bat Man; and Bobby Deniro, what is going on there, ever since the movie Heat, it's like his acting is taking a nose-dive, don't get me wrong, he still up there, in the top three best, he still a monster of an actor, but I guess it's the movies he has picked, not necessarily his acting, after all, he has picked some real good ones too, such as Killer Elite, The Score, and even the Meet the Parents movies. I was completely fooled with the two big names, I figured, they would simply make Travolta talk as little as possible with that fake accent, and the movie would be a complete hit, but I guess that was not the case.

review_title: Two Hollywood Veterans in a Convoluted Mess of a Film
review_detailed_main: Killing Season was a strange film. I wanted to like it alot because it has alot going for it: two great veteran actors, Robert DeNiro and John Travolta, a great setting in the Appalachian mountains in North Georgia, and lots of action and suspense. However, it's faults were too many to overcome. First of all, (and let's get this out of the way, because I'm sure you're all thinking about it), John Travolta's fake Eastern European accent and spray-painted hair was truly awful. At no point in the film was I able to believe that this guy was a real Bosnian unless all Bosnians have a wobbly mumbly drawl, and that's just not true. There are also alot plot holes related to the backstory, the story behind the story, if you will. It just doesn't make sense and to chalk it all up to the fact that the Bosnian war was just downright terrible is not a sufficient enough catalyst for the plot. Travolta's dialogue was also very heavy. He kept talking and talking. Would this guy please just shut up? As well, the violence is appropriate for the story but the decisions made by these two supposed war-hardened soldiers from opposing sides defy logic and common sense. Again, great setting though!

review_title: A film that have so easily been better than it actually is
review_detailed_main:
A retired American soldier (Nicolas Cage) lives isolated in his mountain cabin home. One day he is visited by a former Serbian soldier (John Travolta) who is looking for revenge after the American soldier and his men had killed his men after they came across a massacre and atrocities the Serbs had committed in a village during the Bosnian War. A dangerous game of cat and mouse takes place between the two men.

One of those action films that could have been so much better than it actually is when a cat and mouse capture and torture situation becomes an endurance battle. The film lacks wit and runs out of imagination way too soon, but was a project both Cage and Travolta had wanted to make for years.

Yes, what is the point? I couldn't figure out what the makers of the movie are trying to say. The trailer looked as if it is an action packed flick and it started likewise but seriously it goes no weredrags on and on with some confession s**t going on between the two leads.

Two sophisticated and excellent actors wasted on this movie, only thing good about this movie is the acting.but honestly you will get bored of it too..just because there no plot and proper script.

Anyone who is a fan of Robert De Niro or John Travolta what this movie to see your favorite actor..rest allplease don't waste your time on this.

I watched it because I like both the actors and I felt sorry from them, maybe I saw the movie in a wrong angle (I couldn't find any other) OR the makers made it in a wrong angle ;-)

review_title: Stick with it, it's worth it.

review_detailed_main: Two power hitters go to a baseball game and do there best to hit a home runs. The problem was they were swinging with hockey sticks. Morale: great actors need good equipment. This movie plot and script was terrible, pointless and boring. If it wasn't for RdN and JT no one would see this.

This movie is the live-action adaptation to the cinema of the fictional animated television series Itchy & Scratchy, which is featured in the animated television series The Simpsons, as a part of the The Crusty the Clown Show. Only not silent.

If you like Itchy & Scratchy you will like this movie. There's lot of violent action, traps, blood and pain in an endless game of cat and mouse.

The film's got a pearl of wisdom from the mouth of John Travolta. It goes like this: --Atrocities of war-- "are not the proof of the absence of God, they are the proof of his existence. Because men alone could not be capable of such evil."

review_title: A bit too pretentious for my liking and not worthy for DeNiro or Travolta
review_detailed_main:
(Plot) A Bosnian war veteran Benjamin Ford (DeNiro) in seclusion encounters another veteran involved in the Bosnian War Emil Kovac (Travolta) They befriend one another. Unbeknownst to Benjamin, he is being targeted by Emil.

I was full aware of the STD release for this one. I also read a plethora of bad reviews for this one, but I was still quite excited to see this. Robert DeNiro & John Travolta are two of my favorite actors of all time, so I will rush out to see whatever they star in. DeNiro has become the brunt of many jokes for taking so many roles lately. Hell. I've even seen someone say "He's been Nicholas Caged" I apologize for the digression here, but grow up! Show some class and respect. DeNiro is one of the finest actors to ever grace our screens and is responsible for legendary roles. To say that kind of thing is abhorrently disrespectful. This movie isn't horrible by any means, but it's not that good. It starts off well enough. I was enjoying the banter between DeNiro & Travolta immensely. As soon as it took a turn for the serious, it became increasingly silly. It has plenty of bow & arrow chase sequences which I felt lacked suspense. It also grew rather tiresome. It got to the point where it felt like they were fighting like two 5 year old's fighting over a Christmas toy. It was just completely juvenile in my estimation. The violence factor is rather strong. I cringed in a couple scenes involving torture. Robert DeNiro is solid, even when he's not at his best. It's always a pleasure to watch him go to work. He was able to be sympathetic as well. I enjoyed his monologue in the finale. John Travolta fares a bit worse. His Serbian accent is OK at best, and I didn't get enough character development with him. His chemistry with DeNiro is good, though. Milo Ventimiglia is barely in the movie. It's a rather inconsequential part. He's basically, somewhat the "estranged" son. The ending was not surprising in the slightest, either.

Final Thoughts: This is a watchable affair. Let's face it. Even with DeNiro & Travolta on an off day, it's still better acting than quite a few others. This is worth a look on a rainy day. It's not as bad as people say, but it's not worthy of talents such as Bobby D & Travolta either. It's not something I'll ever watch again.

5.4/10

I know quite well about the historical facts what happened back then in former Yugoslavia. I admit the movie could have been better if they had chosen another war where the background story really could have taken place. To watch this movie you need to forget what really happened and just enjoy a good revenge story, which is really not that bad. At least it was an enjoyable 90 minutes for me, although I have seen much better movies of both actors. I also don't see it as an anti-Serbian movie at all, since both sides and their crimes are portrayed. If there is a lil message in this, it's more that war at all causes people to do bad stuff for which they have to suffer their whole life. In the end it is just an entertaining movie for me, most important is the revenge thought in this movie, nothing more, nothing less.

This movie will keep you on the edge of your seats, both DeNiro and Travolta do an amazing job in portraying their characters. Travolta plays a Serbian sodlier and DeNiro an American soldier who both served in the Bosnian war int the nineties on opposite sides. The movie portrays the Yugoslav conflict well. Most of the action happens in the US but there are some scenes in Serbia. Travolta does great with the accent and Serbian language. Some bloody scenes so don't take your children to it. The ending is surprising and worth seeing. The movie starts off slow but is action packed and it culminates in the amazing ending. I would see the movie again.
It's a letdown having Travolta, and Deniro as it's 2 main actors. Yet still it is boring, and predictable. Major miss!

If this were an April's fool, the prank would be pretty good - but it's not, and it isn't. Ruling out the possibility to laugh it off - leaves for nothing but total disgust.

Set aside the total disregard for historical events: This is, arguably one of the worst films ever made. The overall sensation is that someone squirted ketchup over a Disney nature film. The acting must be among the worst performed by De Niro/Travolta - but they are forgiven. One would have to assume that they realised what a load of crap this is and simply didn't bother to put on a performance.

If you add to the mix that Killing Season, in all likelihood, manages to offend thousands of people who have living memory of the horrors of war - it would be an enigma if Mark Steven Johnson gets funding for anything ever again. The only mitigating circumstance is that the film is so bad that; it will only reach a small audience.

Personally I'm totally against censorship - but, in this case, a minimum of self-regulation would not go a miss.

review_title: Bosnian war victim seeks out American vet to settle score; a message flick
review_detailed_main:
Of all the types of American films that are overdone, for me this is the most dreaded: The message flick. Especially since the message is usually "women can do whatever they want, men don't matter".

Early in the film we see with some scenes from the Bosnian war, including a mass execution of a group of war prisoners by some soldiers. Next, we see Deniro back in the states, milling around his log cabin, with segments of him going from one macho routine to the next- chopping wood, cleaning guns, reading by a crackling fire. I am surprised they didn't have a groin scratching while passing gas segment. Travolta shows up after having gotten some info . about De Niro back home in Eastern Europe. Naturally, they have to insert a baby into the film, so we are treated to some nauseating scenes of DeNiro's grandson, complete with that sound when you open a music box. At this point you know DeNiro is the good guy , and Travolta is in for some suffering.

Travolta attempts to engage DeNiro in a cat and mouse war game, but Robert does not want to play until Travolta threatens DeNiro's family; then, SURPRISE, De Niro is out to kick some butt. The problem with the movie , there is no suspense. Once we see Travolta threaten a child, we know he is the bad guy, and that the ending will show DeNiro reconciling with the family, complete with violins . This in spite of the fact that his wife was having sex with his best friend while he was suffering at war. .So the message is - vigilantism is OK even if you are judge, jury and executioner; women can do whatever they want, men don't matter. Leave it to baby obsessed Hollywood to insert a baby into a war flick.

This is a great little movie, only an hour and half long though so don't expect the back stories of the characters to be to in-depth, De Niro and Travolta offer up some great performances, I would say the first half is more of a thriller, keeping you on the edge of your seat, then the second half is when the action starts and the fight scenes get gory! Iv seen a lot of things online yet there are some scenes in this that had me turning away not being able to watch, I recommend this movie, its a nice change this summer to see a movie based on performances rather than CGI, and De Niro is proving he's not to old when it comes to action, he definitely gives as good as he gets in this one :)

As a US Army veteran that served in Bosnia at the time in question, I was insulted by Di Niro's Ford character. I think if I were a Serb, I'd be even more offended by Travolta's Kovac.

Both characters commit horrible acts, and neither evokes much sympathy from the viewer, and so it's hard to care what happens to them. Di Niro plays the stereotypical maladjusted veteran living alone in the woods, a cliché since the Vietnam War. Travolta's character is even worse, with an accent sounding like Boris from Boris and Natasha cartoons and beard that would be more appropriate on an Amish farmer.

What is really distracting is how little the movie resembles the true history of Bosnia and NATO's involvement. In 1995 NATO conducted an air war against Serb held areas of Bosnia, and by the time US ground forces arrived as peacekeepers, we were not liberating concentration camps, getting in fire fights with Serbs, or executing prisoners. We were dodging land mines, searching for weapons, and trying to keep the peace. The Nazi-like scene of rail cars full of bodies was just that – a Nazi holocaust scene taken off a WWII script and inserted into a more recent genocide. And because it was a relatively recent genocide, you would think Hollywood would show a little more restraint.

(Spoiler alert) The message of the movie – what little there seems to be of one – is that all sides do horrible things, but if you throw away your gun and confess your evil deeds while sitting on a rock in the middle of nowhere, then you can immediately let go of years of anger, make friends, go home and start making your life right again. Uh huh.

review_title: You gotta accept that this movie sucks to enjoy it
review_detailed_main: This movie is absolutely awful as it is De Niro and Travolta torturing each other for most of the time. But it's so bad that it's hard not to laugh out loud for most of these torture parts. Easily De Niro's worst performance and Travoltas SECOND worse (The Fanatic!!!)

The story started interestingly and ended interestingly. In between, the plot: It was on the verge of boredom, but still OK. Too much has been said and not enough done. That was unrealistic. Overall, I give generously 5/10, because of the happy ending.

Boy, was this bad. Really bad. Not even DeNiro nor Travolta could save this movie. DeNiro just seemed to wanna make a quick buck with this one and Travolta's Serbian accent was unbearable. Even his hair looked completely fake. This is probably worst movie both of them have ever done in their careers, I kid you not. Just adorn watch it. It's a total waste of time.

I wasn't going to watch this after reading all the terrible reviews but my husband liked it and asked me to, so I did. I was not disappointed. All the one-star reviews seem to concentrate on saying it was not historically correct in regards to the Bosnia war. I think those people are missing the point of the movie, which in my opinion was more about the relationship between DeNiro's character and Travolta's than historical accuracy. It's a movie and doesn't claim to be a true story. DeNiro was good as always, and Travolta gets a bad rap no matter what he does. I thought he did a good job, including the accent everyone is so focused on. Have any of you seen him in "Love Song for Bobby Long"? The man can act. I also noticed if you keep reading the reviews till you reach the third page, there are quite a lot of people that liked it and gave it 7-10 stars, and said basically what I'm saying, which is it's more of a relationship movie about the different effects of war on people than being about the war itself. Just felt like I needed to put a positive review on here after all the angry sounding "1 star" ones.

Review: This is quite a poorly made film about Travolta trying to take revenge after being shot by DeNiro in the Serbian war. The thing that I didn't like about the film was that, one minute DeNiro is hostage and then the next minute Travolta is hostage, which gets a bit ridiculous after a while. The other thing is Travolta appalling attempt of a Serbian accent. Anyway, the director really lost the chance to make a decent movie with these 2 veteran actors. You can tell that there both not giving there all and the Rambo style concept in the woods really didn't work. The movie really did show that both characters couldn't have been that good at kidnapping because they kept on getting away from each other. Anyway, I did have high hopes for the movie because both actors have made some all time classics, but this movie won't go down as one of them.

Round-Up: What is going on with Travoltas beard and accent in this movie? Anyway, Travolta hasn't made a decent movie for some time and after seeing his future projects, like the Gummie Bear Movie, I can't see him coming out with anything that good soon. It's a shame, because the man can really act, but he just isn't getting the right movies. He's even starting to pop up in TV series, which is never good for an actors career. As for Robert DeNiro, he just seems to be addicted to working. He seems to be starring in some weird movies like Crossfire and Killer Elite, but he will always be taken seriously in Hollywood. As for both of the stars in this movie, I think that they should just call it a bad day at the office because the takings were appalling and personally, the movie isn't one that I will remember.

Budget: N/A Worldwide Gross: $40,000 (Terrible!)

I recommend this movie to people who are into there revenge action thrillers about a Serbian war veteran, seeking revenge. 3/10

review_title: A promising start descends in to a load of trite inanity
review_detailed_main:
STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Morning *** Friday Night ** Sunday Night * Monday Morning

Benjamin Ford (Robert De Niro) was a US foot solider who served on the ground in the Bosnian war in the '90's, but who now lives a quiet, isolated existence in the mountains. However, one man, Emil Kovac (John Travolta), a Serbian man Ford was meant to have killed, cannot forgive and forget and has hunted him down to his mountain retreat. Initially friendly, Kovac soon has Ford locked in a deadly game of cat and mouse.

"De Niro and Travolta, on screen for the first time ever", the publicity on the cover for this film proudly booms. That would be a small screen, however, in this neck of the woods anyway, as Killing Season arrived straight to DVD over here, which sort of sets the bells of doom ringing well beforehand. It's still an interesting pair up, though, but it's quite clear this isn't going to have the sort of quality it would have had if it had came out maybe twenty years ago. It actually opens quite well, after the opening shaky camera battle sequence, establishing an atmospheric tension before the lead paths have even crossed, but somehow when they do, all the components of the machine fall apart, and it just descends on a downward spiral.

De Niro tries to inject his role with some dynamism and gravitas, but you can never shake the feeling that it's another one of his 'pay cheque' roles. Travolta, never the most naturalistic actor, here has a dodgy Croatian accent to carry, along with a silly mountie beard. It's a curious pairing, that doesn't work due to the writing they have to contend with, including an unconvincing meeting, an initial bonding that does nothing to establish any menace or sense of unease, and an unexpectedly reflective and gentle ending that shakes it all up. After all this, you might think the ending would be the best bit, and it is, but in a good way, with some beautiful cinematography of the mountains and a nice, gentle song to go with it.

It's another real time thriller, meaning it's at least a short affair, but that just shows what a shame it is. **

review_title: It doesn't do anything for Robert DeNiro
review_detailed_main:
(2013) Killing Season SUSPENSE THRILLER

Movie uses the Bosnian war as a backdrop to pit, Serbian born, Emil Kovac (John Travolta) going after American soldier, Benjamin Ford (Robert DeNiro) who was enjoying his retirement back in the US, while he was living in an isolated wooden cabin. Both are going to reveal and settle their war commotion differences in the woods. The character, played by Travolta as Emil, was too artificial to be taken seriously, for I never had any grasp at why he had so much hate toward Benjamin when his character did far worst, while joining the army. Also, I don't ever recall any American soldiers ever partake being part of the Bosnian War.

Man, this movie killed me. It's was really painful to watch. I'm not sure if it were entirely to blame on how annoying Travolta's character was or trying to figure out why De Niro even took this role. This movie had so much wrong with it. First off, Travolta is still angry about his near death experience that happened years ago, so he's out for revenge. De Niro is just old and lives out in the middle of the absolute forest, with a family that's just dying to visit, but continuously refuses. In my opinion, this movie is way too scattered around. The fight scenes were iffy and the ending was no where near good. This really makes me wonder of they just took this job just to get out of the house or something. Both are really great actors, obviously. Yet, it didn't show in this film. I plainly found Travolta annoying, especially with that accent and De Niro was not attachable, which doesn't happen a lot. They were only pretty much asked to play their roles because they are well known and exceptional actors. I would honestly save yourself the headache and time and just avoid this movie. It'll do you great good.

review_title: Not unlike the pro wrestling on TV in the 1970's . . .

review_detailed_main:
This could have been much better than it was, it would have needed a new script though, and to be perfectly frank, some better acting too.

Both Robert De Niro and John Travolta played familiar roles, and unfortunately Travolta especially, played his both woodenly, and unconvincingly. The dodgy accent didn't help either.....

The setting for the movie was fantastic though, really beautiful looking country. But obviously that's not enough to lift a movie out of mediocrity.

I liked the premise of the film, but felt let down by what was in all honesty a B-movie played by A-list actors.

The Killing Season was one of those movies that you're not quite sure how it gets made. Who comes up with the idea of having John Travolta play a Serbian and have a battle with Robert De Niro? Honestly, it actually wasn't that bad of an idea but it was just such a slow movie that it made it difficult to watch at times. If this film was any longer I might've fallen asleep. Some of the plot points were a little weak also and Johnny T's accent, while not bad, isn't good enough to make you forget it's John Travolta. Overall, not a terrible movie but pretty mediocre in general. Unless you're watching it for free, don't waste your time.

I skipped past this movie many times while searching for some entertainment on Amazon. I thought that Travolta could never pull off the role: Vinnie Barbarino playing a Serbian? Seriously? Sure, one could find faults, but I enjoyed this movie. Maybe because my expectations were low. I figured I'd watch a bit, then switch to another flick. But I stuck with it. Glad I did, because it was better than the current run of the mill productions that litter the streaming sites. The movie had my attention; wondering how the constant exchange of control would result in the end. And I thought the end was appropriate.

For those who pan the movie due to historical inaccuracies, you need to relax and see the movie for what it is, entertainment. If you're looking for accurate portrayal of US involvement in Middle East conflicts, then go read a book or - for the lazy lot - watch a documentary.

review_title: Entertaining but this movie feels like there was no 'soul'
review_detailed_main:
So, riddle-me-thistypically when you get two great actors such as Robert DeNiro and John Travolta in one flick you have an instant movie classic, right? Well, let me solve this riddle and inform you that this isn't always case and Killing Season (2013) is one of those.

Don't get me wrong, this certainly was not a bad movie. But neither was it a particularly good movie. This simply was a movie that seems like it "didn't happen". It didn't have a soul, nor conviction. In other words, the movie started and then it ended. 1 ½ hours later and there was no meat in-between in spite of some high action scenes. I can't find the right way to describe how this movie missed-the-mark other than it felt like DeNiro and Travolta did a personal favor for a movie- director friend.

Killing Season opened with a disturbing scene depicting some awful events that took place during the Bosnian War. While this scene was quite emotional this could have set the stage for a good plot, especially considering the star talent of both Academy Award winning actors. There was some attempt by the director to create an emotional attachment with the characters throughout the film. Yet in spite of the greatest of Robert and John's acting talent, it just didn't work well for me.

Therefore I can easily summarize Killing Season as this: "Start movie : Some action here in the middle : End movie". The movie felt like it wanted to be great but it was just blah. This was a movie that seemed to have great potential so I was a bit disappointed in this under- achiever. If it weren't for Robert and John acting in this film then Killing Season would get a much lower rating.
Travolta's shoe polish hair dye, his awful accent, and numerous getaways makes for a ridiculous movie with shallow characters. Skip this one.

review_title: Two survivors of the Bosnian conflict fight it out deep in the woods.
Disappointment after a great premise and plot
review_detailed_main: I am a fan of Travolta's energetic acting , always. De Niro is a supreme powerhouse and both of them together ,makes for a recipe of deliciousness. But the movie becomes predictable and some routine play acting after a great build up. Tension among the actors develop after they have a lovely late evening tet-e-tete. Where they drink, discuss philosophy of the war, trade war stories and some bad jokes and sing off tune. The setting was excellent. Dark brooding jungle, rains and loneliness. But the cat and mouse game fell apart. I think the writers didn't have it in them to create something truly great, they had a great idea, and that's it. Either because of paucity of funds or lack of creative abilities, the movie fell far short of it's premises to become a great one.

Sent into Bosnia to stop Serbian aggression, "Colonel Benjamin Ford" (Robert De Niro) discovers a death camp operated by a special Serbian unit. A fire fight ensues and several of the perpetrators are rounded up and subsequently executed by Colonel Ford's squad. However, one specific person named "Emil Kovac" (John Travolta) manages to survive and after a lengthy stay in the hospital finally recovers and decides to find out who was responsible and upon doing that sets out to America to kill the man in charge. Meanwhile, Colonel Ford is having a difficult time reconciling what he saw in Bosnia and the actions he felt he had to take and is unaware that someone is out to get him until he shows up on his doorstep in the middle of the wilderness. Now rather than reveal any more of this movie I will just say that it was interesting at first but some of the scenes were rather repetitive and from then on it proceeded to go downhill fast. Additionally, the fake Serbian accent used by John Travolta also got old rather quickly as well. In any case, I don't think this is a bad movie by any means but it certainly doesn't merit any high marks either and for that reason I have rated it accordingly. Average.

The tagline for his moody, atmospheric, harrowing and insightful films is 'The purest form of war is one on one' and that generally encircles the mood of the film from beginning to end. Written by Evan Daugherty and directed by Mark Steven Johnson this is a small cast film that concentrates much of the destructive impact of war on those who fight it and survive it. Many people seem to expect more from a film than simply viewing how war eats the brain and memory and after-war life, concentrating responses on actors' accents and implausible encounters, but the message is delivered well if you are open to hear it.

KILLING SEASON is the confrontation of two veterans of the Bosnian War, an international armed conflict that took place in Bosnia and Herzegovina between 1 March 1992 and 14 December 1995 and is still remembered for the Bosnian ethnic cleansing campaigns and the violent and terror-inspiring means the civilian population of another ethnic or religious group from certain geographic areas endured murder, torture, arbitrary arrest and detention, extra-judicial executions, rape and sexual assaults, confinement of civilian population in ghetto areas, forcible removal, displacement and deportation of civilian population, and deliberate military attacks or threats of attacks on civilians and civilian areas. One veteran is American, Benjamin Ford (Robert De Niro) whose life has become one of being a recluse in the back hills of Appalachia, ignoring his family and struggling with the atrocities he not only witnessed but participated in: the other a Serbian, Emil Kovac (John Travolta) who narrowly escaped assassination by Ford and the American troops and since the war has been hunting for Ford to make him confess his war crimes and suffer the consequences. Ford and Kovac meet surreptitiously at Ford's little cabin, and at first exchange food and drink only to have the reality surface of Kovac's intent to kill Ford. The remainder of the film is a cat-and-mouse game that braces the wills of each survivor in treacherous manners that make each man reopen old war wounds and find a new universality in the effects of war on the human mind.

The film is shot in Georgia (cinematography is by Peter Menzies, Jr) with flashback black and white and sepia toned footage of the horrors of the Bosnian War. De Niro and Travolta manage these difficult roles well in this basically two-person film (Ford's son and daughter in law and new baby are adroitly played by Milo Ventimiglia and Elizabeth Olin, and the early scenes in Serbia are polished by performances by Diana Lyubenova, Kalin Sarmenov and Stefan Shterev). The tension is underlined by a fine musical score composed by Christopher Young.

This film may not meet everyone's expectations of big noisy extravaganzas, but as a powerful antiwar statement is works exceptionally well.
